results.title: Tabu: a story of the south sea
results.creator_credit: Friedrich W. Murnau and A Murnau-Flaherty Production
results.brief_description: The love of a young couple violates a local taboo in this folk tale of the Pacific Islands. Although filmed on location, Tabu is in no sense anthropological in intent. The sense of freedom that seems to have been released in Murnau by the South Seas is expressed stylistically. The inevitable tragedy set in motion by the virility of the young hero is intensified by the rhapsody of textures and the sensuous, sometime homoerotic, play of light on the human body. The space in the frame and its evocation beyond is charged with the menace of a hostile world. Murnau’s last film was initially to be a collaboration with Robert Flaherty but Flaherty pulled out early in the production and sold his interest to Murnau. Tabu was shot as a silent film in 1929 and released in 1931 with a musical soundtrack.

results.title: Table looms
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Weaving”
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. Shows samples of cloth which can be made on multi-shaft looms such as the table loom.

results.title: Tabaran
results.creator_credit: Mark Gould, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, EMTV Papua Niugini, Kino Eye Pictures and Mark Gould Productions
results.brief_description: The Australian band Not Drowning Waving in 1988 went to Papua New Guinea to record sessions with Tabaran musicians. Their interest in the music was partly the attraction to the different instruments but also the new sounds created in a period of post-colonialism where western influences can be heard within rich sounds of traditional PNG music. The documentary traces Not Drowning Waving’s recording of the album Tabaran in PNG and the band’s involvement with local PNG communities. A rich cultural picture is the result as the band travels through a dynamic mix of different tribal cultures within the country, the colonial past, and contemporary street life.

results.title: Tabaluga. Volume 5
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Tabaluga GbmH
results.brief_description: A German-Australian co-production created by Peter Maffay, Gregor Rottschalk and Rolf Zuckowski, Tabaluga is the last surviving dragon on earth. Using a combination of fire and flight, both peaceful options, Tabaluga fights his nemesis the evil snowman Arktos, intent on ruining Tabaluga’s home of Greenland by covering it with snow and ice, thus making it inhospitable. Popular with adults and children alike, “Tabaluga” is in its third series and a feature film is in production. “Someone is cheating” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Morris the Ice Welder is banished from Ice World with toy friend Annabel, tired, hungry and friendless. Arktos plans to take over Greenland and challenges the peaceful country to the Arctic Games; the winner takes all, including several hectares of the loser’s land. “Mr Nice guy” (story by John Palmer): Arktos demands a new flavour of ice cream and sends James, disguised as a clown, to Greenland to fetch fruit to make fruit ice cream. Surprisingly, he finds himself befriended by Tabaluga. “Too much salt is detrimental to the health” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Arktos promises his disgruntled workers that he will give them more ice cream if they work harder. The only problem is that Ice World does not have enough water to maintain the supply and Arktos devises a cunning plan to build a dam between Ice World and Greenland, supposedly an advantageous gift to Greenland.

results.title: Tabaluga. Volume 4
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Tabaluga GbmH
results.brief_description: A German-Australian co-production created by Peter Maffay, Gregor Rottschalk and Rolf Zuckowski, Tabaluga is the last surviving dragon on earth. Using a combination of fire and flight, both peaceful options, Tabaluga fights his nemesis the evil snowman Arktos, intent on ruining Tabaluga’s home of Greenland by covering it with snow and ice, thus making it inhospitable. Popular with adults and children alike, “Tabaluga” is in its third series and a feature film is in production. “Dragons don’t cry” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Tabaluga is surprised to discover he can cry after crashing while flying. Travelling with Happy, they come across a strange fruit that Happy eats. Arktos’ number one henchman James is also interested in the fruit and takes it back to his master. The next day, both Arktos and Happy suffer from a sleeping sickness. “The Big cloud” (story by Gregor Rottschalk, Heike Lage): Snowballs packed with a secret formula that turns them into thick, black clouds are assailing Greenland. Counteracting the power will require activating the molten lava in the volcano through the assistance of an army of special ants. “The Visitors who came in from the cold” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Productivity is down at Arktos’ sardine factory and there is a mass walkout by penguin staff, including their brethren working throughout the rest of Ice World. En masse, the penguins head for the sunny climes of Greenland. Voices provided by Keith Scott, Robyn Moore, Jamie Oxenbould.

results.title: Tabaluga. Volume 3
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Tabaluga GbmH
results.brief_description: A German-Australian co-production created by Peter Maffay, Gregor Rottschalk and Rolf Zuckowski, Tabaluga is the last surviving dragon on earth. Using a combination of fire and flight, both peaceful options, Tabaluga fights his nemesis the evil snowman Arktos, intent on ruining Tabaluga’s home of Greenland by covering it with snow and ice, thus making it inhospitable. Popular with adults and children alike, “Tabaluga” is in its third series and a feature film is in production. “The Wiser head does not give in” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Arktos is firing snowballs at the volcano, covering it in a layer of white, rendering the volcano frozen and threatening to take over the rest of Greenland. Tabaluga is given an ultimatum, himself in exchange for the safety of the other occupants of Greenland. “Two birds with one stone” (story by Gregor Gottschalk, Heike Lage): A slumbering Tabaluga is carried by a group of soldier ants back to their Queen. She blames Tabaluga for the destruction of her Blue Army but soon comes to realise they have a common enemy in Arktos. “Moonstruck” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Tabaluga vows to fly to the moon, even though no one else has successfully ever made it there. He seeks the assistance of Arktos and his powerful telescope to see it. Voices provided by Keith Scott, Robyn Moore, Jamie Oxenbould.
